natural solution: Since $x^2 - x - 6 = (x + 2)(x - 3),$ $x$ must satisfy $x \le -2$ or $x \ge 3.$  And since a square root is always nonnegative, $x$ must satisfy $2x - 3 \ge 0.$  Then $x \ge \frac{3}{2},$ so $x$ must satisfy $x \ge 3.$

Note that for $x \ge 3,$ both sides are nonnegative (and defined), so we can square both sides, to obtain the equivalent inequality \[x^2 - x - 6 < 4x^2 - 12x + 9.\]This simplifies to $3x^2 - 11x + 15 > 0.$  This inequality is satisfies for all real numbers, so the solution is $x \in \boxed{[3,\infty)}.$
